thread.title: Beaches has hottest night in city
thread.title_full: Beaches has hottest night in city

title: Beaches has hottest night in city
text:
Use keywords to search content on this website Search Use keywords to search content on this website media_camera Nic, 12, and Alex Foster, nine, getting in a last minute surf before heading back to school tomorrow. The northern beaches was the hottest place in Sydney last night, hitting 27C at midnight Sarah Swain, Manly Daily January 31, 2017 2:15pm 
THE Northern Beaches had the hottest night of anywhere Sydney last night — and the heat is set to continue. 
On Monday night, Terrey Hills hit a low of 27.4C degrees at 12.13am, and for most of the night, temperatures didn’t drop below 29C. media_camera Nic, 12, and Alex Foster, nine, at Newport Beach 
Hottest nights are measured by the lowest temperature reached. 
Rob Toggart, Bureau of Meterology duty forecaster, said the suburb, home to the northern beaches ‘main weather station, beat the rest of Sydney. 
“The hottest air was sitting just over the city and Terry Hills is high enough to just poke through that,” he said. 
The record breaking night was just the latest in the list of sweltering figures this month. media_camera Friends cool off this month at South Curl Curl pool. Picture: Adam Yip/ Manly Daily 
The same night, a new summer weather record was set overnight at Observatory Hill — seven nights with minimum temperatures of 24C. 
Meanwhile, the same location has had nine days of 35C plus temperatures this summer, which equals the summer record of 1895/96. 
Terrey Hills’ hit 38.3C today, before a cool change swept through around lunch time. media_camera Chloe Mitchell and Channel Mitchell with children Izaiah, six, Alegra, four, Romen, seven, Shaniah, two, and Giselle, one, enjoy the beach 
Bureau of Meterology experts are set to release January’s weather figures tomorrow- and it's expected to be declared one of the hottest on record. 
Mr Toggart explained why. 
“One of the key features of this part January has been high pressure systems sitting over the Tasman Sea.,” he said. 
“Those systems direct north to north westerly winds over NSW, so you’ve got very hot air mass sitting over central parts of Australia that comes into NSW. 
This week will be slightly cooler with showers, climbing back to 36 C on Sunday. Most viewed
